questions.question_text: Which two commands are used to query the arp-table of a logical switch? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
get logical-switch <vni-or-uuid> arp-table
Display local ARP table for the specified logical switch.
Option Description
<vni-or-uuid> VNI or UUID argument
Allowed pattern: ^[0-9]+$|^[0-9a-fA-F]{8}-([0-9a-fA-F]{4}-){3}[0-9a-fA-F]{12}$
Example
nsx-controller-1> get logical-switch 857212c6-3d87-4a4a-9700-0c9d23f74f1c arp-table
VNI IP MAC TransportNodeId
5000 172.16.130.12 00:50:56:8e:1b:21 857212c6-3d87-5d5d-9700-0c9d23f74f1d
Mode
Basic
Availability
Controller

https://vdc-download.vmware.com/vmwb-repository/dcr-public/cc42e3c1-eb34-4567-a916-147e79798957/8264605c-a5e1-49a8-b603-cc78621eeeab/cli.html#get%20logical-switch%20%3Cvni-or-uuid%3E%20arp-table

Please note that the environment for this exam is NSX-T 3.0 and not other versions!

Selected Answer: BC
Tested on Transport Node and worked like charm

BC is correct answer

https://vdc-download.vmware.com/vmwb-repository/dcr-public/46158b4f-e75f-49a6-8014-056750afa658/a944ad7a-6043-41d7-91a2-99f602996c77/NSX-T%20Command-Line%20Interface%20Reference.html

The command can be used as follows:

get logical-switch <vni-or-uuid> arp-table

Source: 
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/1003724
YES - BC is correct
Agree with B and C - details here: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/2.3/com.vmware.nsxt.admin.doc/GUID-F66C5813-E619-473D-90CD-48E8E93E0FE3.html

according to NSX-T Command-Line Interface Reference:
"get logical-switch <vni-or-uuid> arp-table"
yes bc
I think BC

questions.question_text: What are the supported N-VDS modes?
questions.answer_description:
N-VDS Mode: There are 2 modes for N-VDS: Standard or Enhanced Datapath.
Reference:
http://www.vstellar.com/2018/08/03/learning-nsx-t-part-8configuring-transport-zone-and-transport-nodes/

discussion.content:
B, D are correct

choices.B: 9000 MTU is required for active-active state replication
choices.C: global load-balancing is required to support NSX Manager DNS namespace

discussion.content:
yes, D
"Requirements for Multisite Deployments: The bandwidth must be at least 1 Gbps and the latency (RTT) must be less than 150 ms."

Ans is D

questions.question_text:
An organization with two data centers is planning an active-active multi-site deployment of NSX-T Data Center.
The two data centers have this network connectivity configuration:
✑ Redundant 1Gbps links with 200 millisecond RTT
✑ Global load balancing is not being utilized
✑ 1600 MTU
✑ vSphere 6.5U2
Which configuration prevents the use of an active-active architecture?

choices.E: The virtual machines running on the KVM transport node are not connected to the WEB-LS Segment.
choices.C: The virtual machines running on the KVM Transport Node are not connected to the VDS.
choices.A: Since the Compute Manager is disconnected in Simplified UI, the WEB-LS segment will not be realized on the KVM Transport Node.
choices.B: The virtual machines running on the KVM Transport Node are connected to the WEB-LS segment, but are in Powered Off state.
choices.D: The KVM Transport node has hardware issues and will not realize the WEB-LS Segment.

questions.question_text:
An NSX administrator has created a segment named WEB-LS from the simplified UI and noticed the segment is not realized on the KVM Transport node.
What are two possible causes for this issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Computer Manager is used only for deployment/configuration phase to help configure ESXi hosts
B & E should be answer!

Its definetly not A. Computer Manager is used only for deployment/configuration phase to help configure ESXi hosts. Its not necessary. We could configure Tarnsport Nodes on the ESXi hosts without Computer Manager. I've never meet with Computer Manager set for KVM host. KVM host always were configured as a stand alone host. The most suite answer is B and E. C also is not good becaouse we actually don't connect VMs with VDS directly. We connect's VMs with segments or other PortGroups. If it would be hardware problem with KVM host then not only one VM will have some problem. So B and E are the most suite for me.

It's B: the question is on how to enable the service, not on how persistently enable it. In D the command is wrong: the right command is 'set service ssh start-on-boot' without the 'enable' on tail. C is a mix of two commands and will not work.

B is Correct, Question is tricky here where it asks just about "enabling SSH service" and not about start.

Enable SSH and configure it to start automatically when the NSX-T Edge node is restarted.
start service ssh
set service ssh start-on-boot

C is correct...
 If you did not enable SSH while installing the appliance, you can use the set service ssh start-on-boot command to enable the SSH service. 

https://vdc-download.vmware.com/vmwb-repository/dcr-public/46158b4f-e75f-49a6-8014-056750afa658/a944ad7a-6043-41d7-91a2-99f602996c77/NSX-T%20Command-Line%20Interface%20Reference.html#set%20capture%20session%20%3Csession-number%3E%20[file%20%3Cfilename%3E]%20[count%20%3Cpacket-count%3E]%20[expression%20%3Cexpression%3E]

Agree with B: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Validated-Design/services/deployment-of-nsx-t-edge-nodes-on-bare-metal-hardware-for-vmware-cloud-foundation-310/GUID-A38E3949-1781-49BD-86F9-18056C07E0CE.html

comments.content:
set service ssh start-on-boot is not exists in the Choices :)
Answer is B

discussion.content: Looks like "C" is correct. set service ssh start-on-boot - this will auto-start ssh service on every reboot.
http://www.vmwarearena.com/enable-ssh-in-nsx-t-manager/
